SiC and B-doped SiC were prepared and employed to support Ni components for the catalytic hydrogenation of nitroarenes. The B-doping of SiC evidently improved the catalytic activity of Ni/SiC, and the activity of Ni/SiC-B0.5 catalyst was 2.4 times higher than that of undoped Ni/SiC. Further investigations revealed that the incorporation of B substituted some Si atoms in SiC lattice and thus produced carbon vacancies. These vacancies will result in a heterogeneous distribution of surface charges on SiC, thereby enhancing the adsorption and activation of nitroarenes on the support surface. In addition, the carbon vacancies can also act as donor centers for capturing dissociated hydrogen species, thus enhancing the hydrogen spillover from Ni to SiC surface. Graphical Abstract Keywords Ni/SiC catalysts B doping Hydrogenation of nitroarenes Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Aniline and its derivatives are valuable intermediates broadly used in the synthesis of organic dyes, pigments, pharmaceuticals and pesticides [1–3]. The production methods of aniline include iron powder reduction, hydrazine hydrate reduction, catalytic hydrogenation, etc. Among these methods, the catalytic hydrogenation of nitroarenes is an efficient and environmentally friendly route that has received widespread attention [4]. Noble metal catalysts such as Au [5], Pt [6], Pd [7], Ru [8] exhibited efficient catalytic performance for the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene. However, the expense and scarcity of precious metals have greatly limited their industrial applications. Therefore, the development of cheap and resource-rich non-noble metal catalysts for the important hydrogenation process is of great importance. Non-precious metal catalysts for nitrobenzene hydrogenation have been studied deeply [9]. Supported Co [10], Fe [11], and Ni [12] catalysts have exhibited good catalytic performance for the process. Liu et al. employed thin carbon layers to protect the chemical state of active component Co, and achieved efficient hydrogenation of nitroarenes to corresponding anilines [13]. Zhang et al. developed multi-layer N-doped graphene encapsulated Ni catalysts for the hydrogenation of nitroarenes containing sulfur impurities [14]. Wei et al. found that the electron was transferred from Ni to graphene after some oxygen-containing functional groups were modified, allowing electron-rich graphene to activate and hydrogenate chloronitrobenzene [15]. The properties of supports have significant impacts on the performance of supported catalysts. SiC is a novel carrier material, and it can not only disperse metal active components, but also provide active sites for some reactants [16–18]. In the nitrobenzene hydrogenation on Pd-Au/SiC catalyst, H2 was dissociated on the Pd surface and then migrated to the SiC surface where it reacted with nitrobenzene molecules adsorbed there [19]. It is established that electron-deficient nitro group (-NO2) is easily adsorbed on electron-rich sites [20]. Therefore, the construction of electron-rich sites on SiC surface would help improve the catalytic activity of SiC supported catalysts for nitrobenzene hydrogenation. The B doping to SiC can change the intrinsic electric structure of SiC, and B-doped SiC has shown enhanced activity for photocatalytic water splitting [21]. In this work, we reported that the B doping increased the electric density of Si sites and thus the surface of B-doped SiC became more beneficial to hydrogen spillover and nitrobenzene adsorption. As a result, the catalytic activity of B-doped SiC supported Ni increased by 2.4 times in comparison with Ni/SiC. 2 Results and discussions Under the reaction conditions described in 1.3 of the experimental section (see the supporting information), the selectivity of various SiC-based catalysts for aniline can reach 99.9%, but the catalytic activity (nitrobenzene conversion) is various for different catalysts. When Ni/SiC is used as the catalyst, the nitrobenzene conversion is only 32.5%, and the reaction rate is 1.5 mol nitrobenzene/(mol Ni·h). When using Ni/SiC-B x catalysts, the nitrobenzene conversion is significantly improved. Among them, the Ni/SiC-B0.5 catalyst can give a reaction rate of 3.6 mol nitrobenzene/(mol Ni·h), which is 2.4 times of that of Ni/SiC under identical conditions. Subsequently, the influences of different B doping levels on the catalytic performance were studied, as shown in Fig. 1. As the doping level of B in SiC increases, the nitrobenzene conversion gradually increases. When the B doping level is 0.5, the catalyst shows the highest activity. As the B doping level continues to increase, the corresponding catalysts show a declined catalytic activity. By raising the reaction temperature to 90 °C, the Ni/SiC-B0.5 catalyst can achieve a nitrobenzene conversion of nearly 100% (the reaction rate is 4.9 mol nitrobenzene/(mol Ni·h)). The results indicate that the B doping in the SiC support has an important role in the enhancement of the catalytic activity of Ni nanoparticles. When the amount of substrate is increased to 10 mmol, the conversion rate is ∼29.6 mol nitrobenzene/(mol Ni·h). In comparison with the reported non-noble metal-based catalysts (Table S1), the Ni/SiC-B0.5 is one of the most excellent catalysts for nitrobenzene hydrogenation under mild conditions (90°C, 1 MPa H2). The XRD patterns of as-prepared SiC and SiC-B x (x=0.1, 0.3, 0.5, 1, 2) samples are shown in Fig. 2a. From the patterns, all the strong diffraction peaks can be attributed to the different facets of β-SiC. Besides these peaks, no other diffraction peaks are observed in all samples, this indicates that B doping does not alter the phase structure of β-SiC. However, as the B doping level increased, the characteristic peaks of β-SiC shifted to higher 2θ values, indicating an obvious lattice shrinkage. The detailed magnifying of the diffraction peak (111) is illustrated as inset in Fig. 2a. Table 1 shows the lattice constant a and interplanar spacing d of the (111) planes of SiC, which are obtained from the diffractograms of Fig. 2a. Both the values of a and d decrease with the increase of B doping level, further confirming the lattice shrinkage. With increasing B doping, the SiC lattice shrinks, indicating that B is preferentially accommodated in Si sites. Because B has a smaller atomic radius (0.095 nm) than Si (0.134 nm), the replacement of Si by B will result in the lattice shrinkage [22]. The above results suggest that B has been doped into the lattice of SiC [23]. The chemical state and surface properties of SiC-Bx samples were determined using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The B 1 s XPS results of SiC-B x samples are shown in Fig. 2b-d and Fig S1a. According to literature, the binding energy (BE) of B 1 s in silicon shows a sharp peak at 187.4 eV, it will shift to a higher BE when B is doped in SiC [24]. The peak at 192–193 eV is attributed to the B-O bond of B2O3 [25]. In Fig. 2b-d and Fig. S1a, the BEs in the range of 192–193 eV and ∼190 eV can be ascribed to B-O and B-C bonds, respectively. Increasing the B doping level, the percentage of B-C bonds on samples also increases. Specifically, the B-C proportion in SiC-Bx gradually increases from 46% (SiC-B0.1) to 58% (SiC-B0.3), 73% (SiC-B0.5) and 77% (SiC-B1). The above results also suggest that B has been successfully doped into SiC and replaced some Si sites in SiC. The BEs of Si 2p in different SiC-B x samples were also investigated by XPS. As shown in Fig. 3 and Fig. S1b, the BE value of Si 2p shifts slightly from 101.5 eV (SiC) to 101.2 eV (SiC-B0.1), 100.8 eV (SiC-B0.3), 100.4 eV (SiC-B0.5), and 98.9 eV (SiC-B1), suggesting an electron enrichment on Si atoms. In the SiC lattice, each C atom is bonded to four adjacent Si atoms, and each Si atom is bonded to four C atoms. When some Si sites in SiC are replaced by B, there will form carbon vacancies adjacent to the B due to the different valence of B3+ and Si4+. The Si atoms adjacent to the carbon vacancies will generate dangling bonds, which increase the electron density around the Si atoms and form electron-rich Si sites. Theoretical calculations have indicated that the carbon vacancies in SiC will form donor centers, which easily capture hydrogen and form Si-H bonds [26]. According to the inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES)results, the Ni contents are 4.1 wt%, 4.3 wt%, 4.8 wt%, 4.7 wt% and 4.5 wt% for Ni/SiC, Ni/SiC-B0.1, Ni/SiC-B0.3, Ni/SiC-B0.5 and Ni/SiC-B1, respectively, suggesting Ni particles can be successfully loaded on SiC and B doped SiC supports. The transmission electron microscopic (TEM) images show that the average particle sizes of Ni in Ni/SiC and Ni/SiC-B0.5 are 4.4 nm ( Figs. 4a) and 4.0 nm (Fig. 4b), respectively. The interplanar spacings of Ni particles are 0.203 nm, corresponding to the Ni (111) plane for both samples (Fig. 4c and d). However, no diffraction peaks of Ni or NiO can be found in the XRD patterns of either of the two catalysts. (Fig. S2), this may be due to the small size of Ni particles. The above results suggest that the B doping does not significantly affect the size of Ni particles. From the Ni 2p XPS results of Ni/SiC and Ni/SiC-B x (Fig. S3), Ni components mainly exist in the oxidized state in Ni/SiC and Ni/SiC-B0.1. However, Ni0 species appear both in Ni/SiC-B0.3 and Ni/SiC-B0.5. With the increase of B doping, the metallic Ni disappears in Ni/SiC-B1. These results indicate that the doping of a suitable amount of B into SiC can alter the interaction between Ni and SiC. The TPR profiles of Ni/SiC and Ni/SiC-B0.5 catalysts are shown in Fig. 5. As can be seen, the catalysts display two reduction peaks. The first peak of Ni/SiC catalyst appears at 291 °C. This is the reduction peak of the amorphous NiO, which has a weak interaction with SiC. The second peak appears at 547 °C, which is the reduction peak of NiO with strong interaction with SiC [27,28]. For the Ni/SiC-B0.5 catalyst, the first peak appears at 189 °C, which is far lower than that of Ni/SiC. Meanwhile, the hydrogen consumption in this region also significantly increases. Because the pre-reduction temperature of Ni/SiC and Ni/SiC-B is only 450 °C, catalytically active Ni components mainly originate from those reduced at lower temperature. Obviously, there are more active Ni components in Ni/SiC-B0.5 catalyst. Therefore, the B doping has greatly promoted the reduction of NiO and the formation of more active Ni components. H2 dissociation is usually the rate-determining step in nitrobenzene hydrogenation, and a catalyst with high hydrogen dissociation capacity tends to have a high level of hydrogenation activity [29]. The adsorption capacity of Ni/SiC and Ni/SiC-B0.5 catalysts for H2 were measured by pulse adsorption at 30 °C. The saturation adsorption of H2 on Ni/SiC was 1.8 μmol/g, whereas it was 31.2 μmol/g for Ni/SiC-B0.5. The adsorption capacity of Ni/SiC-B0.5 for H2 is greatly higher than that of Ni/SiC, and this may be attributed to the B-doping resulted carbon vacancies [26]. The enhanced H2 adsorption is consistent with the high reactivity of Ni/SiC-B0.5. Additionally, we introduced an H2 flow (30 mL/min) to the mixture of WO3 with Ni/SiC or Ni/SiC-B0.5 catalysts at 30 °C for 40 min, a significant color change of the mixture of Ni/SiC-B0.5 and WO3 was observed, while the color of the mixture of Ni/SiC and WO3 remained almost unchanged (Fig. S4). These results indicate that the B doping can indeed enhance hydrogen spillover from Ni to the surface of SiC. The IR spectra of H2-treated Ni/SiC and Ni/SiC-B0.5 catalysts were also recorded (Fig. S5). An adsorption band at 3014 cm−1 was observed from the infrared spectra of H2-treated Ni/SiC-B0.5 catalyst, which can be assigned to the vibration absorption of C-H bond. However, the same adsorption band was not found in the Ni/SiC catalyst. This also proves that the B doping can enhance the hydrogen spillover on the SiC surface [30]. However, the characteristic absorption of Si-H bond was not observed, which may be due to its weak IR absorption. In summary, the B doping results in the appearance of electron-rich Si sites on the SiC surface, which are beneficial to the reduction of NiO and hydrogen spillover. According to our previous work on photocatalytic hydrogenation of nitrobenzene, nitrobenzene is adsorbed and activated on the surface of SiC [19]. Therefore, in-situ FTIR was used to study the adsorption of nitrobenzene over different catalysts, and the results are shown in Fig. 6. For nitrobenzene, the absorption bands caused by the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibration of -NO2 are in the range of 1625–1540 cm−1 (v asym) and 1400–1360 cm−1 (v sym), respectively [31,32]. As shown in Fig. 6a, the adsorption of nitrobenzene on both SiC and Ni/SiC exhibits two distinct absorption bands at ∼1521 cm−1 and ∼1347 cm−1, corresponding to the v asym and v sym of N-O bonds in the -NO2 group. After nitrobenzene was adsorbed on SiC-B x and Ni/SiC-B x , both the v asym and v sym of N-O bonds were blue-shifted to ∼1532 cm−1 and ∼1347 cm−1 respectively. The blue shift of the v asym and v sym of N-O bonds is due to the enhancement of N-O and C-N bonds, respectively [33]. This indicates that electrons transfer from the SiC-Bx surface to the electron-withdrawing -NO2 group. In addition, the absorption bands of nitrobenzene on pure SiC-B x and it supported Ni catalyst are identical, suggesting that nitrobenzene is mainly adsorbed on the surface of SiC support. The adsorption of nitrobenzene molecules on other different carriers and their Ni catalysts were also studied, and the results are shown in Fig. 6b. The -NO2 absorption bands are not clearly observed on pure Al2O3 and SBA-15. In comparison, the v sym (NO) and v asym (NO) bands are found at 1342 cm−1 and 1517 cm−1 on Ni/ SBA-15, and 1343 cm−1 and 1518 cm−1 on Ni/Al2O3. The above results indicate that nitrobenzene mainly adsorbed on the Ni particles surface, this is clearly different from the adsorption on SiC based catalysts. CO poisoning experiments were employed to explore the surface reaction processes of nitrobenzene hydrogenation. Ni/SiC-B0.5 catalyst was firstly treated at 150 °C in 0.5 MPa CO for 30 min, and then used for the nitrobenzene hydrogenation under the given conditions for 1 h. The nitrobenzene conversion in this case was only 1.7%, which was 1/14 of the conversion on fresh Ni/SiC-B0.5 catalyst under the same conditions. This means that the CO treatment can make the Ni/SiC-B0.5 catalyst poisoned. Next, a temperature-programmed reaction process was used to confirm the role of surface species in the hydrogenation reaction [34]. First, 50 mg catalyst was sandwiched in quartz wool in a quartz tube, and reduced at 150 °C for 30 min under H2/N2 flow (VH2=10%) (step A). In the process, H2 was dissociated on Ni surface and the dissociated H species then migrated to the surface of SiC. Second, Ar was used to purge the catalyst for 30 min to remove the physically adsorbed H2 on the catalyst surface (step B). Then, the nitrobenzene was fed into the reactor tube via an Ar flow, and the exhaust gas was analyzed by in-situ FTIR (step C). For the fresh Ni/SiC-B0.5 catalyst, the vibration band of –NO2 (1540 cm−1) in gaseous nitrobenzene and the ring stretching vibration band (1506 cm−1) in gaseous aniline produced by the nitrobenzene hydrogenation can be clearly seen in the infrared spectra after 5 min, as shown in Fig. 7a. This indicates that the chemo-adsorbed hydrogen on the catalyst surface can hydrogenate nitrobenzene to aniline. To further demonstrate that the nitrobenzene molecules are activated on the surface of SiC-B x support, CO was fed into the reactor tube to poison Ni after step A. Surprisingly, the adsorption band of –NO2 and the ring stretching vibration band of aniline can also be observed in the infrared spectra after 5 min of the mixed gas of CO/nitrobenzene injection, the results are shown in Fig. 7b. Since the Ni surface has been poisoned by CO, the above control experiments suggest that the SiC-B surface is capable of activating nitrobenzene molecules. To confirm the activation of nitrobenzene on the surface of support, dilution experiments were carried out according to the following processes. Firstly, 300 mg of SiC-B0.5 was dispersed in an ethanol (5 mL) solution of nitrobenzene (1 mmol) under stirring for 1 h, then the suspension was dried to obtain a sample of SiC-B0.5 with nitrobenzene adsorbed on its surface, and the sample was marked as NB/SiC-B0.5. Subsequently, 15 mg of Ni/SiC-B0.5 catalyst was mixed with different masses of NB/SiC-B0.5 for the dilution experiments carried out under the condition of 90 °C, 1 MPa H2 and 30 min. After the reaction, the mixture of catalyst and NB/SiC-B0.5 was again dispersed in ethanol (3 mL) and gas chromatography was employed to analyze the content of aniline in ethanol. The results of above experiments (Fig. S6) further confirm that the SiC-B0.5 carrier can activate nitrobenzene and the hydrogenation process is realized through the reaction between nitrobenzene adsorbed on the support surface and spillover hydrogen dissociated on Ni surface. Under optimal reaction conditions, except the quantity of reactants is 2 mmol, the kinetic behaviors of nitrobenzene hydrogenation on Ni/SiC-B0.5 and Ni/SiC were studied and the results are shown in Fig. 8. The kinetic profile of Ni/SiC for nitrobenzene hydrogenation (Fig. 8a) suggests that nitrobenzene could be converted into aniline with initially a nearly zero-order in concentration, and no other intermediate was observed. From the kinetic curve of Ni/SiC-B0.5 (Fig. 8b), it can be seen that it also conforms to the characteristics of a zero-order reaction in the initial stage (within 1 h). Besides aniline, other intermediates such as nitrosobenzene, azoxybenzene and azobenzene can also be observed. As the reaction time lengthens, the selectivity of aniline gradually increases while the selectivities of other products continuously decrease. Haber first proposed a reaction network for nitrobenzene hydrogenation including direct and condensation pathways based on electrochemical reduction experiments [35], and the mechanism has been widely used to explain the experimental results of nitrobenzene hydrogenation [6]. From the kinetic profiles of Ni/SiC-B0.5 and Ni/SiC, it can be concluded that Ni/SiC catalyzed hydrogenation of nitrobenzene follows a direct reaction pathway, while the reaction pathway over Ni/SiC-B0.5 changes to the condensation pathway, which may be attributed to the adsorption behaviors changes of reactant and immediate when B doped to SiC. Then, different kinds of substituted nitroarenes were used as substrates to investigate the general applicability of Ni/ SiC-B0.5 for the hydrogenation of nitroarenes. As shown in Table 2, Ni/SiC-B0.5 can transform all of these nitro compounds to corresponding anilines with high activity and selectivity. The electron-withdrawing nitroarenes (entries 1–4) showed higher activity than the electron-donating ones (entries 5−6). Especially for nitroaromatic hydrocarbons (entries 2–4) containing sensitive groups such as -CN, -CHO, and -COOH, they can also be selectively converted into corresponding anilines. Reaction conditions: 1 mmol of reactant, 50 mg of Ni/SiC-B0.5 catalyst in 10 mL of anhydrous ethanol. 1 MPa H2 and 90 °C. One of the advantages of heterogeneous catalysts is their good reusability. The stability tests were carried out and the results are shown in Fig. 9. It can be seen that the selectivity of aniline shows no decrease during the 5 times used, while the activity of Ni/SiC-B0.5 appears an obvious degradation. The catalyst after 5 tests was analyzed by ICP-OES and TEM. Compared with the fresh catalyst (4.7 wt%, Ni), the Ni content of the used catalyst decreased to 3.7 wt%. TEM images of the used catalyst showed that the mean size of Ni particles had grown from 4.0 nm to 9.4 nm (Fig. S7). Therefore, the Ni loss and particle growth may result in the declined catalytic activity. 3 Conclusion We have shown that Ni supported on B doped SiC exhibits good performance for the hydrogenation of nitroarenes to anilines with molecular hydrogen. The excellent catalytic activity originates from the electron-rich Si sites that generated by the B doping. In B doped SiC, the replacement of Si atoms by B leads to the generation of carbon vacancies and electron-rich Si sites adjacent to the vacancies. During the catalytic hydrogenation, metallic Ni component performs the dissociation of H2 and the support surface activates nitrobenzene. The dissociated hydrogen species then migrate to the support surface and react with adsorbed nitrobenzene. The B doping can enhance the reduction of Ni oxides and the hydrogen spillover on SiC surface. Therefore, the Ni supported on B doped SiC shows improved catalytic activity for the nitroarenes hydrogenation. This study offers a novel idea and reference for designing new catalysts for the selective hydrogenation of nitroarenes. coredata.dc:description: SiC and B-doped SiC were prepared and employed to support Ni components for the catalytic hydrogenation of nitroarenes. The B-doping of SiC evidently improved the catalytic activity of Ni/SiC, and the activity of Ni/SiC-B0.5 catalyst was 2.4 times higher than that of undoped Ni/SiC. Further investigations revealed that the incorporation of B substituted some Si atoms in SiC lattice and thus produced carbon vacancies. These vacancies will result in a heterogeneous distribution of surface charges on SiC, thereby enhancing the adsorption and activation of nitroarenes on the support surface. In addition, the carbon vacancies can also act as donor centers for capturing dissociated hydrogen species, thus enhancing the hydrogen spillover from Ni to SiC surface.
coredata.dc:title: Enhanced catalytic performance of B-doped SiC supported Ni catalysts for the hydrogenation of nitroarenes
